Award.AwardTitle: DiD: MIning Relationships Among variables in large datasets from CompLEx systems (MIRACLE)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
Some of the most pressing questions for social scientists -- ranging from efforts to better understand the interactions between humans and the environment to predicting how an aging population will impact the US and global economy -- require making sense of large amounts of data. As a result, social scientists are increasingly using new computational modeling methods to explore the dynamics and consequences of human interactions. These new methods, including agent-based models, provide ways to explore research questions that cannot be investigated using traditional statistical approaches. But appropriate methods to mine, analyze, and synthesis large-scale complex model output data in order to answer social science research questions are still lacking. Traditional analysis methods are designed for data that are linear, continuous, and normally distributed, while data from models of complex socio-ecological systems are non-linear, discontinuous, and power-law distributed. In this project, the researchers seek to address these challenges by developing, applying, and disseminating an integrated environment for analysis and visualization of data generated by complex systems models. An important broader impact is that the research will lead to tools that will allow stakeholders, policy makers, and the general public to explore, interact with, and provide feedback on otherwise difficult-to-understand models.

The project builds on ongoing research by the project team, and uses the NSF-supported CoMSES Net Computational Modeling Library as a platform to make this suite of collaborative, open-source tools broadly available. This community environment will allow any users to post model output along with associated metadata, visualize and analyze output data, comment on and share analyses, and conduct comparative and meta-analysis, drawing on data from other projects. This cyber-infrastructure will provide semi-automated means of discovering relationships that can lead to new theories about how social systems work, test the realism of simulations against knowledge from empirical systems, and propose new research directions to explore.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The MIRACLE project was an international collaboration under the Digging Into Data program, involving collaboration by science teams from the US, Canada, the UK, and The Netherlands. The goals of this project were to develop community, on-line accessible tools to visualize and test relationships among variables in complex systems, with a specific focus on semi-automated discovery of context-sensitive relationships. CoMSES Net (http://www.comses.net), at Arizona State University, represented the US team, supported by NSF. 

The original role of CoMSES Net was to provide a platform for deploying and disseminating the results of the project. Over the course of the project, the role of the US CoMSES Net team expanded to also include assisting in software development of a prototype online environment for the analysis of computational model data and sharing research workflows. 

The MIRACLE prototype allowed users to upload, analyze, and share high dimensional output data from complex simulation models in a web-based environment. Scientists could upload data, R analysis scripts, and model and provenance metadata into a public project; this upfront curation then allowed external users to explore the output data via integration with the Radiant R Shiny app (http://vnijs.github.io/radiant/), rerun and reparameterize visualization generating data analyses using a DeployR instance to re-execute the R scripts on the output data, and then share and comment on these outputs. The tool was intended to be an exploration of the possibility space for sharable, reproducible and reparameterizable computation applied to modeling outputs. The MIRACLE prototype environment was built on a Python based technology stack including Django Rest Framework (https://www.djangoproject.com), PostgreSQL, Celery, and Docker. User contributed projects consisted of data, R analysis scripts and RMarkdown documents (http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com) to carry out and document analyses, Packrat (https://rstudio.github.io/packrat/) bundled R packages needed for the analyses, and metadata for the project. These were stored in a PostgreSQL database container used by the Django app. An R script execution container based on Microsoft’s DeployR Open software (https://deployr.revolutionanalytics.com) was used to run analysis scripts in a sandboxed environment. The Radiant platform (http://vnijs.github.io/radiant/), which combines R and Shiny, was used for GUI initiated online analyses. Although the initial focus was to support reparameterizable R scripts it could be expanded to support other programming languages, such as Python.

CoMSES Net created platforms on the CoMSES Net site to host and disseminate materials from this project as originally proposed, and established a collaborative development environment in GitHub for the duration of the project. Currently the deployment URL, https://miracle.comses.net, has links to the published paper and an example screencast of the prototype software and what it was intended to do. It will continue to be maintained and expanded as needed in the future as part of the CoMSES Net web portal.

In collaboration with other team members, CoMSES Net staff developed base docker images (https://hub.docker.com/r/comses) to run DeployR and Radiant for the creation and sharing of reparameterizable R data analysis workflows. This approach turned out to be brittle due to the dependency on the rapidly evolving DeployR platform. However, the team learned a great deal of good practices for running Docker from this that we will leverage as we build out the larger CoMSES Net cyberinfrastructure for open science as an NSF Big Data Spoke.

This project has provided an invaluable experience to CoMSES Net personnel, especially Academic Professional Researchers Lee and Pritchard about the requirements for developing long-term reproducible workflows and using tools like Docker. We have brought this expertise into a series of new, and more extensive collaborative initiatives for open computational science currently being developed by CoMSES Net as an NSF Big Data Spoke. The MIRACLE project also led to a successful application for computing resources from Compute Canada, which is currently hosting the CoMSES BD Spoke internet portal.

The MIRACLE project is an exemplar of social-science computing and collaborative team science. The project members faced and overcame numerous challenges of working across different academic traditions, funding models, and academic institutions in different countries. Project members have continued to collaborate in subsequent efforts to improve cyberinfrastructure for socio-ecological science and are actively engaging with open science initiatives related to reusable, interoperable, and reproducible computation.

The results of this project have been disseminated in a series of conference presentations in Europe (Glasgow, UK and Toulouse, France) and the US (at the international Complex Systems Society annual meeting in Tempe, and at the Research Bazaar, or #ResBazAZ for short, a worldwide festival promoting the digital literacy emerging at the center of modern research, Tucson, AZ). We have also disseminated the results in a journal paper (citation below) and via the CoMSES Net web portal.

Jin, X., Robinson, K., Lee, A., Polhill, J.G., Pritchard, C., Parker, D.C., 2017. A prototype cloud-based reproducible data analysis and visualization platform for outputs of agent-based models. Environmental Modelling & Software 96, 172–180. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.envsoft.2017.06.010.
